{"comments": {"id": 26865, "count": 54, "talk_id": 2245}, "threadId": 26865, "requested_language_english_name": "English", "current_talk": "2245", "description": "Liver cancer is one of the most difficult cancers to detect, but synthetic biologist Tal Danino had a left-field thought: What if we could create a probiotic, edible bacteria that was \"programmed\" to find liver tumors? His insight exploits something we're just beginning to understand about bacteria: their power of quorum sensing, or doing something together once they reach critical mass. Danino, a TED Fellow, explains how quorum sensing works -- and how clever bacteria working together could someday change cancer treatment.", "event": "TED2015", "language": "en", "language_swap": false, "name": "Tal Danino: Programming bacteria to detect cancer (and maybe treat it)", "slug": "tal_danino_we_can_use_bacteria_to_detect_cancer_and_maybe_treat_it", "series_slug": null, "speakers": [{"id": "2478", "slug": "tal_danino", "is_published": true, "firstname": "Tal", "lastname": "Danino", "middleinitial": "", "title": "", "description": "Synthetic biologist", "photo_url": "https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/dde2c6bc9b16e967eca843d65b3ab63d77258dd8_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "", "whotheyare": "Tal Danino explores the emerging frontier of combining biology and engineering (and art). He is a 2015 TED Fellow.", "whylisten": "

Tal Danino's research explores the emerging frontier of combining biology, engineering and medicine. His work as a synthetic biologist focuses on reprogramming bacteria to detect and treat diseases in our bodies such as cancer.

Originally from Los Angeles, Danino received B.S. degrees from UCLA in Physics, Chemistry and Math, and received his Ph.D. in Bioengineering from UCSD. He did a postdoctoral fellowship at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and is currently an assistant professor at Columbia University in New York.

Danino's work has been published in scientific journals and highlighted in several popular press venues. He actively develops "Bio-Art" projects that share perspectives and stories about science with recent projects featured in the New York Times, WIRED, and the Wall Street Journal.

Danino explores the emerging frontier of combining biology and engineering (and art). He is a 2015 TED Fellow.", "whylisten": "

Tal Danino's research explores the emerging frontier of combining biology, engineering and medicine. His work as a synthetic biologist focuses on reprogramming bacteria to detect and treat diseases in our bodies such as cancer.

Originally from Los Angeles, Danino received B.S. degrees from UCLA in Physics, Chemistry and Math, and received his Ph.D. in Bioengineering from UCSD. He did a postdoctoral fellowship at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and is currently an assistant professor at Columbia University in New York.

Danino's work has been published in scientific journals and highlighted in several popular press venues. He actively develops "Bio-Art" projects that share perspectives and stories about science with recent projects featured in the New York Times, WIRED, and the Wall Street Journal.

"}], "speaker_name": "Tal Danino", "tags": ["TED Fellows", "bacteria", "biology", "cancer", "health"], "title": "Programming bacteria to detect cancer (and maybe treat it)", "video_type": {"id": "1", "name": "TED Stage Talk"}, "viewed_count": 1303773}]}
author: Tal_Danino;
title: Programming bacteria to detect cancer (and maybe treat it)

aws-transcripts.transcript: you may not realize this, but there are more bacteria in your body than stars and our entire galaxy. This fascinating universe of bacteria inside of us is an integral part of our health, and our technology is evolving so rapidly that today we can program these bacteria like we program computers. Now, the dog that you see here, I know it looks like some kind of sports play, but it is actually a blueprint of the first bacteria program I developed. And like writing software, we can print and right D n a into different algorithms and programs inside of bacteria. What this program does is produces fluorescent proteins in a rhythmic fashion and generates a small molecule that allows back here to communicate and synchronize as you're seeing in this movie, The growing colony of bacteria that you see here is about the width of a human hair. What you can't see is that our genetic program instructs these bacteria to each produce small molecules, and these molecules travel between the thousands of individual bacteria. Tell him when to turn on and off and bacteria synchronized quite well at this scale. But because the molecule it synchronizing together could only travel so fast in larger colonies of bacteria. This results in traveling waves between bacteria that are far away from each other, and you can see these waves going from right to left across the screen. Now our genetic programme relies on a natural phenomenon called quorum sensing, which bacteria trigger coordinated and sometimes virulent behaviors once they reach a critical density, you can observe quorum sensing an action in this movie where a girl in colony of bacteria only begins to glow once it reaches a high or critical density in our genetic program continues producing these rhythmic patterns of fluorescent proteins as the colony grows outwards. This particular movie and experiment we call the supernova because it looks like an exploding star. Now, besides programming these beautiful patterns, I wondered, What else can we get these bacteria to? D'oh and I decided to explore how we can program bacteria to detect and treat diseases in our bodies like cancer. One of the surprising facts about bacteria is that they can naturally grow inside of tumors. This happens because typically tumors are areas where the immune system has no access is the bacteria find these tumors and use them as a safe haven to grow and thrive. We started using probiotic bacteria, which are see fact here that has a health benefit and found that when orally delivered to mice, thes probiotics would selectively grow inside of liver tumors. We realized that the most convenient way to highlight the presence of the probiotics, and hence the presence of the tumor's, was to get these bacteria to produce a signal that would be detectable in the urine. And so we specifically programmed these probiotics to make a molecule that would change the color of your urine, indicate the presence of cancer. We went on to show that this technology could sensitively and specifically detect liver cancer, one that is challenging to detect otherwise. Now, since these bacteria specifically localised the tumors, we've been programming them to not only detect cancer but also to treat cancer by producing therapeutic molecules from within the tumor environment that shrink the existing tumors. And we've been doing this using Corum scenting programs like you saw in the previous movies altogether. Imagine the future taking a programmed probiotic that could detect and treat cancer or even other diseases. Our ability to program bacteria and program life opens up new horizons in cancer research. And to share this vision, I worked with artistic loonies to create the symbol of the universe made entirely out of bacteria or cancer cells. Ultimately, my hope is that the beauty and purpose of this microscopic universe conspire new and creative approaches is for the future of cancer research. Thank you.
